Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Physical characterization of extreme, deep-subsurface microorganisms from Homestake Gold Mine
Award.AbstractNarration:
Earth's deep subsurface is a typically extreme, energy-starved ecosystem. This vast biosphere represents the largest microbial habitat on Earth and is a similar environment to those found in the subsurface of other planets. This project aims to grow and characterize microbial life in Earth's deep continental subsurface, specifically at the former Homestake Mine, in South Dakota. It was recently discovered that the continental deep subsurface is a populated ecosystem where single-celled organisms survive. In the continental subsurface, microbial life has been detected 3.3 km below Earth's surface. Only a few deep subsurface microorganisms have been grown in the laboratory hence how they survive remains unclear. Biological samples from the deep subsurface will not grow using traditional microbiological cultivation techniques. Therefore, successfully cultivating its residents requires innovative technology. Dr. Hiroyuki Imachi at JAMSTEC-Yokosuka in Japan has designed low-flow bioreactors to cultivate fastidious, low energy-adapted anaerobes (organisms that use a terminal electron acceptor other than O2) from the subsurface.

For the current study, water and rock samples collected from 5,000 feet below surface at Homestake Mine will be incubated in low-flow bioreactors. The bioreactors contain mineral substrates and media designed to mimic the deep subsurface environment from which samples were collected. Subsequent collections of effluent from the reactors have yielded enrichments of subsurface anaerobes, excellent for isolation and metabolic characterization of typically low-density, slow-growing microorganisms. The methods to taxonomically and metabolically characterize these previously unstudied microorganisms will include rRNA and functional gene sequencing, lipid analyses, metabolic substrate usage, and qPCR and FISH probe design for in situ environmental detection. Because Earth's subsurface is analogous to that of other planets, understanding how life exists in Earth's deep subsurface will help in the search for life in the subsurface of other planets. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
arth’s deep subsurface is a typically extreme, energy-starved ecosystem. This vast biosphere represents the largest microbial habitat on Earth and is a similar environment to those found in the subsurface of other planets. This project aims to grow and characterize microbial life in Earth’s deep continental subsurface, specifically at the former Homestake Mine, South Dakota, USA. Biological samples from the deep subsurface will not grow using traditional microbiological cultivation techniques. Therefore, successfully cultivating its residents requires innovative technology. The host scientist for this EAPSI project, Dr. Hiroyuki Imachi at JAMSTEC-Yokosuka, Japan, has designed continuous-flow bioreactors to cultivate fastidious, low energy-adapted anaerobes (organisms that use a terminal electron acceptor other than O2) from the subsurface. For the current study, water samples collected from 5,000 feet below surface at Homestake Mine were incubated in bioreactors at Dr. Imachi’s lab. The bioreactors contain mineral substrates and media designed to mimic the deep subsurface environment from which samples were collected. Collection of effluent from the reactors has yielded enrichments of subsurface anaerobes, excellent for isolation and metabolic characterization of deep subsurface microorganisms.  The methods to characterize these previously unstudied microorganisms include rRNA and functional gene sequencing, lipid analyses, metabolic substrate usage, and probe design for in situ environmental detection. 

            During the summer 2014 EAPSI fellowship, three microorganisms (Bacteria and Archaea) were enriched from deep continental subsurface environments. One bacterium, within the family Spirochaetales, constitutes the first laboratory isolate of a new genus of bacteria. The energy metabolism and carbon utilization pathways of this organism are currently being characterized for publication in a peer-reviewed journal. The second bacterium, a new member of the genus Thermincola, is only the third member of that genus to be grown in the laboratory. It is a chemolithotrophic organism, reducing iron oxide minerals for energy gain. The third microorganism enriched during the EAPSI fellowship is in the domain Archaea. It is a member of the phylum Thaumarchaea. This is a recently discovered phylum. These archaea are globally distributed: they are abundant in soils, freshwater and marine water columns, freshwater and marine sediments. However, the Thaumarchaeota enriched during the EAPSI fellowship is the first that has been grown from the deep subsurface. Core lipids for this novel Archaean were analyzed, and a unique lipid structure was found in this enrichment. This culture is under further investigation to understand the phylum’s pivotal role in the global nitrogen cycle and to confirm the unique lipid biosignatures found in this deep subsurface enrichment.
